content.subtitle: There is no doubt that higher education has some serious issues, even existential crises to overcome if it is going to have a claim to…

virtuals.subtitle: There is no doubt that higher education has some serious issues, even existential crises to overcome if it is going to have a claim to…

paragraphs.name: 7bbf
paragraphs.text: I’m getting really sick of articles like these, where some guy with an alt-education product to sell comes on the internet to talk about how worthless a college degree, or college itself is, based on a conception of higher education that is conveniently unencumbered by facts.

e598dcfde04a.title: Continuing the harmful opinion that the purpose of education is to make the most money.

paragraphs.name: 9d8b
paragraphs.text: Continuing the harmful opinion that the purpose of education is to make the most money. One of the worst capitalist and market-based opinions in the world. If you go to college solely to get a job, you’re probably right. But I went to college to learn a lot of things that I would have never had the chance to learn without college.

939e0f25cca6.title: Read the last paragraph of this article first to view the axe that is being ground here.

content.subtitle: The point of college is to provide a well rounded, educational background that can be applied to many different problems. College is the…

virtuals.subtitle: The point of college is to provide a well rounded, educational background that can be applied to many different problems. College is the…

paragraphs.name: a4ca
paragraphs.text: Read the last paragraph of this article first to view the axe that is being ground here. Mr Morehouse, who obviously has not raised children to college age, is right about one thing. Your college degree is worthless, because it’s the education that matters.

9c36efa7188.title: I can point out the absurdity of college all day long.

content.subtitle: But at the end of the day, I must concede: as long as you don’t drop out or take out too much debt, college is totally worth it.

virtuals.subtitle: But at the end of the day, I must concede: as long as you don’t drop out or take out too much debt, college is totally worth it.

You can burn the stupid piece of paper, but you can’t destroy the tangible and intangible benefits of engaged work…

Someone with a college degree will make, on average, over 30% more than a high school graduate over their lifetime. Studies have also show…

821505b9f36c.title: I disagree with the entire premise of this essay.

paragraphs.name: 2a53
paragraphs.text: I disagree with the entire premise of this essay. It is impossible to put a price on the value of education. Understanding human culture, science, art, psychology, psychology impacts your enjoyment and appreciation of life, and the empathy you feel towards each-other. How SAD life would be if everything is just about financial gain.

paragraphs.name: d4b3
paragraphs.text: This depends on your degree. Liberal arts and certain fields sure. Sciences and medicine where the pre-requisite knowledge has a higher barrier to entry I’d disagree.

Vocational degrees, like medical professionals, engineers, accountants or lawyers still can offer a return on investment that beats self education on average, I’d argue. But those professions do not interest the majority of people. And while…

Where is your data? Strong opinion and fact aren’t exactly the same thing. Again, I agree almost wholeheartedly. Having spent far too much time in college myself, I can…

paragraphs.text: You are quite a salesman… but I’m not buying.

paragraphs.name: 8afe
paragraphs.text: My college degrees were the greatest thing I ever did for myself and my life. path. Not because they guaranteed an entry level job, but opened doors for me to worlds I never considered, nor never thought I’d access.

1453e9257fba.title: There is a great section in Todd Rose’s book The End of Average about how major companies have…

paragraphs.text: There is a great section in Todd Rose’s book The End of Average about how major companies have moved away from using degrees, GPAs, even majors, etc. as hiring criteria. When they studied the characteristics of their most effective employees, they found that the kinds of things you are talking about were a much better indicator of a valuable employee.

bef3c2d3e635.title: I agree with most of what you’re saying here, but college isn’t dead or not worth it.

content.subtitle: A push for tuition-free higher education (which is done in countries around the world, and our own country in the past) would also make…

virtuals.subtitle: A push for tuition-free higher education (which is done in countries around the world, and our own country in the past) would also make…

paragraphs.name: 3eba
paragraphs.text: I agree with most of what you’re saying here, but college isn’t dead or not worth it. It simply needs to change — in short, educationneeds to stop being about the degree or credential. The more employers devalue degrees, the less school will be about degrees anymore. Good.

paragraphs.name: cbed
paragraphs.text: I’m with you on that, and a greater variety of degrees. However, most jobs do require a degree to be hired. Let’s be honest. A portfolio will get you a long way, though. But, remember, not all fields are design and tech.

Nevertheless some graduates gain an understanding of the world that facilitates critical assessment of contemporary issues in society, among other things. Obviously not every…

d41ae7fc39ca.title: You have an opinion. Opinions are worthless.

paragraphs.name: 5b25
paragraphs.text: You have an opinion. Opinions are worthless.

paragraphs.name: 56a7
paragraphs.text: So. This is a post about degrees. I met my wife on a campus, but guess what? After I flirtily said “Hi”, she didn’t ask, “Are you current on tuition payments?”. You can have every single element of the college experience — including sitting in classrooms — without registering or paying a dime in tuition. No one does, because they’re there for the paper, not the “intangibles”. You want the parties? Move to a college town. You want a cool career? Do some real work.

Smart, hard-working people can quickly and easily create a more powerful signal than a college degree to demonstrate their value in the marketplace. Remember, the degree screams, “I’m about the same as other degree holders.” If you’re better, you need better information than a degree to show it.

paragraphs.name: 45bf
paragraphs.text: Your College Degree is Worthless

paragraphs.name: 56a7
paragraphs.text: So. This is a post about degrees. I met my wife on a campus, but guess what? After I flirtily said “Hi”, she didn’t ask, “Are you current on tuition payments?”. You can have every single element of the college experience — including sitting in classrooms — without registering or paying a dime in tuition. No one does, because they’re there for the paper, not the “intangibles”. You want the parties? Move to a college town. You want a cool career? Do some real work.

paragraphs.name: 2fbd
paragraphs.text: “But most companies list degrees as requirements!”

paragraphs.name: da6d
paragraphs.text: Companies don’t require degrees, they require information. With a little creativity and hustle, you can provide better info in better ways. Oh, and as a general rule, the more interesting the company, the less they care about degrees.

paragraphs.name: b08a
paragraphs.text: This isn’t some far-flung, soon-to-be, if the AI and the internets and the drones and the 3D printers do the exponential thing prediction. This is today. It’s already here. College is dead (here I am saying it on a TED talk-like stage, so you know it must be true).
